questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office with complaints of irregular menstruation. She has had only two periods in the last year. Menarche was at age 12, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until 12 months ago. The patient also reports feeling flushed at night without provocation and experiencing occasional dyspareunia with post-coital spotting. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. The patient has Tanner stage V breasts and pubic hair. Pelvic examination reveals a small anteverted uterus and minimal vaginal rugations. Abdominal examination is within normal limits. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum TSH is 3.2 µU/mL. Which of the following set of hormonal changes will most likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea for 12 months, hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia, in combination with age <40 years and physical examinations findings of minimal vaginal rugations, is consistent with primary ovarian insufficiency or POI (also known as premature ovarian failure or POF). The patient can sometimes experience postcoital spotting secondary to vaginal dryness.

Primary ovarian insufficiency is defined as failure of ovulation secondary to ovarian dysfunction before the age of 40 years. It is usually secondary to absent or dysfunctional follicles that have stopped developing and secreting estrogen in response to gonadotropin stimulation. When this happens, the pituitary gland attempts to restore balance by increasing production of gonadotropins (LH and FSH); however, the follicles don’t respond, so there are still low levels of estrogen. This pattern is called hypergonadotropic (high levels of gonadotropins) hypogonadism (low levels of ovarian hormones).

POI can be spontaneous (i.e. idiopathic or secondary to autoimmune destruction, Turner syndrome, Fragile X syndrome) or induced (secondary to early bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy or gonadotoxic therapies i.e. chemotherapy and radiotherapy). Clinically, it is characterized by menopausal symptoms, like oligo-amenorrhea, infertility and symptoms of estrogen deficiency (hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia and frequent headaches) before age 40.  

Option Analysis

✅  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin Increased  Increased  Increased  Decreased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH Estradiol  Prolactin Decreased Decreased or normal Decreased Decreased  Normal :
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is caused by the decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses from the hypothalamus, leading to decreased levels of LH, FSH and estradiol. It can occur in females who maintain a very low calorie diet.
❌  GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin NormalDecreasedDecreased Decreased Increased:
Incorrect: An elevated prolactin with decreased levels of FSH, LH and estradiol are suggestive of prolactinoma. Patients can present with bilateral breast discharge, visual changes and frequent headache, in combination with amenorrhea.
❌   GnRH  FSH  LH  Estradiol  Prolactin NormalNormal/decreasedNormal/increasedNormal Normal :
Incorrect: The imbalance of LH/FSH ratio in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) can result in the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. PCOS  is characterized by hyperandrogenism (e.g., acne and hirsutism) and testosterone levels may be elevated. This patient with menopausal symptoms most likely has estrogen deficiency.
❌  GnRH FSH LH Estradiol Prolactin DecreasedUndetectableUndetectableUndetectable Normal :
Incorrect: Patients with congenital GnRH deficiency (Kallman syndrome) can present with very low or undetectable levels of GnRH, FSH and LH. It is unlikely in this patient, as she had a normal menstrual cycle previously.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 1, presents to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 13. Since then, she had a regular 28-day cycle with no dysmenorrhea that stopped 3 months ago. Past medical history is significant for two missed abortions, the last of which was 6 months ago, managed via dilation and curettage. She has a healthy 5-year-old daughter born via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient has not had any hot flashes or vaginal dryness. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Speculum examination shows moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of secondary amenorrhea, together with a history of an intrauterine procedure (dilation and curettage) makes the diagnosis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) most likely.  

Asherman syndrome is an acquired disorder that results from trauma to the basal layer of endometrium after which it fails to regenerate and undergoes fibrosis, replacing the normal tissue with multiple bands of collagen (adhesions) that stick to each other. The fibrosed endometrium becomes unresponsive to hormonal stimulation leading to amenorrhea, infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss. Common causes include dilation and curettage following spontaneous abortion (as seen in this patient), cesarean section and other intrauterine procedures like myomectomy or curettage in non-gravid uterus.  

Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis, which can also be used therapeutically to cut the adhesions with a scissor or laser.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamic dysfunction:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a disorder caused by hypothalamic dysfunction leading to disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Common risk factors include stress, anorexia nervosa and excessive exercise, and the condition can therefore be seen in young athletes. It is unlikely in this patient with normal lifestyle habits and body mass index. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels makes this cause less likely.
❌ Accelerated ovarian follicle depletion:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with irregular menstrual cycle, hot flashes and vaginal dryness, none of which are seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with premature ovarian failure typically have elevated FSH levels due to the loss of negative feedback from the lack of circulating estrogen.  
✅ Fibrosis of endometrial stratum basalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ectopic implantation of endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in posterior cul-de-sac). This patient has had none of these complaints, making this diagnosis less likely. 
❌ Low levels of serum thyroxine:
Incorrect: Although amenorrhea can be seen in hypothyroidism, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance and other findings not seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels make this cause less likely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, presents to the clinic because of heavy and painful menstrual bleeding for the past 2 months. The pain starts with the onset of menstrual bleeding and has now become severe in intensity. Her last menstrual period was a week ago. Menarche was at age 11. Her menstrual cycle is regular, with 5-6 days of heavy bleeding. She is sexually active with her male partner and denies any pain during intercourse. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for 2 years treated with metformin and Neisseria gonorrhoeae cervicitis as a teenager, for which she received appropriate treatment. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Bimanual examination shows a uniformly enlarged, mobile, tender and boggy uterus. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface
Subclinical infection of the upper genital tract

questions.solution:
The clinical findings of heavy and painful menstrual bleeding, together with the tender and uniformly enlarged (globular), boggy (soft) uterus on exam makes adenomyosis the most likely diagnosis in this case.  

Adenomyosis is defined as the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The exact pathophysiology is unknown, but it is thought to develop from invagination of endometrial basalis into the myometrium. The ectopic tissue is sensitive to hormonal stimulation throughout the menstrual cycle and mostly presents in multiparous women (between the age of 40 and 50 years) with heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination shows a mobile, uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus. It is important to contrast adenomyosis from leiomyomas, which may also present as an enlarged uterus; however, leiomyomas result in an irregularly enlarged, nontender uterus, rather than a uniformly enlarged, tender uterus in adenomyosis.  

Ultrasound and MRI are helpful in evaluation; however, the diagnosis is usually confirmed after hysterectomy, which is also the definitive treatment. For women who have not completed childbearing, hormonal treatment (e.g., levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices, estrogen-progestin contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors and oral GnRH antagonists) may be effective for reducing heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, as in endometriosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ectopic endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. It commonly presents with dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and deep dyspareunia. In endometriosis, the uterus is normal in size and often immobile (fixed).
❌ Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface:
Incorrect:  Endometrial polyps result from hyperplastic overgrowths of endometrial tissue. They typically present with abnormal uterine bleeding, most commonly intermenstrual bleeding (without dysmenorrhea). Tamoxifen therapy is a major risk factor. Physical examination is usually normal, in contrast to this patient’s findings.
❌ Benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation:
Incorrect: Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) result from benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation. The condition usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menses, pressure symptoms like constipation, noncyclic pelvic pain, and an irregularly enlarged uterus. This patient has a uniformly enlarged uterus and cyclic pelvic pain.
❌ Subclinical infection of the upper genital tract:
Incorrect: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can sometimes present as a subclinical infection of the upper genital tract. Although this patient is at high risk (given the history of N. gonorrhoeae cervicitis), subclinical PID is usually asymptomatic and presents with failure to conceive.
✅ Endometrial tissue in myometrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic to establish care. She is starting a new job as a receptionist and wants to "take care of her irregular periods.” Her menarche was at age 14 and she has been having irregular periods since then. Review of systems is significant for deepening of voice. Past medical history is unremarkable. She only takes over the counter multivitamins. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination shows papulo-pustular acne on the face and a receding hairline. Pelvic examination reveals normal external genitalia and a mobile and nontender uterus with no adnexal masses. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with irregular menses and obesity, together with findings concerning for hyperandrogenism (deepening of voice, receding hairline), is typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Ultrasound should be performed to confirm the diagnosis as per Rotterdam criteria. Such patients are at increased risk of developing endometrial carcinoma in the long-term.

PCOS is a result of dysfunction in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis which causes high pulses of GnRH, resulting in an imbalance of LH/FSH release from the pituitary. The end result is a lack of LH surge, leading to failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. This causes unopposed estrogen exposure on the endometrium. Moreover, anovulation results in decreased progesterone, allowing excessive endometrial build-up and thus increasing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent carcinoma. In addition, increased adiposity in PCOS also increases estrone, further raising the risk.

Other long-term complications that are associated with PCOS include nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, metabolic syndrome, coronary artery disease, mood disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety) and sleep disorders (e.g., hypersomnia, obstructive sleep apnea)  

Option Analysis

❌ Ovarian cyst rupture:
Incorrect: Ovarian cyst rupture is not a complication of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), as PCOS does not actually cause cyst formation (a misnomer). The cystic spaces seen on ultrasound are immature follicles rather than cysts. As such, incidental finding of cystic ovaries on imaging without clinical features of PCOS does not require further evaluation.
❌ Narcolepsy:
Incorrect: Although PCOS is associated with increased risk of developing certain sleep disorders (hypersomnia and obstructive sleep apnea), it is not associated with increased risk of developing narcolepsy.
❌ Virilization:
Incorrect: Virilization is not seen in PCOS, as the testosterone levels are elevated but not to the degree necessary to produce frank masculinization. If there is evidence of virilization, such as clitoromegaly, alternate diagnoses should be considered (e.g. testosterone-secreting tumor).
✅ Endometrial carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ovarian cancer:
Incorrect: PCOS is not associated with increased risk of developing ovarian cancer and does not require additional screening.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the office with complaints of abnormal vaginal bleeding for the past two days. The patient states that she soaked 4 sanitary pads yesterday. Menarche was at age 14, and her menstrual periods had been irregular for the last few years before menopause, which she underwent at the age of 51. Past medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder managed by paroxetine for the last 15 years. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in her father and hypertension in her paternal grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33.5 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows blood clots in the vagina. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Endometrial biopsy is shown below:    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following risk factors in this patient’s history is the most significant in the development of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with obesity (BMI 33.5 kg/m2) with postmenopausal bleeding and endometrial biopsy findings of glandular hyperplasia and nuclear atypia is most likely suffering from endometrial hyperplasia.  

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as the proliferation of endometrial glands that results in an increased number of glands relative to the stroma as compared to normal endometrium. It occurs when there is an increase in estrogen levels without accompanying increase in progesterone. Obesity is a significant risk factor for this condition because it increases the conversion of androgens into estrogens. Other common risk factors include causes that result in increased exposure to estrogen, such as:  

  •  early menarche 
  •  late menopause 
  •  chronic anovulation 
  •  nulliparity 
  •  estrogen-producing tumors  
  •  certain medications, such as tamoxifen or estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy. 
Endometrial hyperplasia increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer. Histologically, hyperplasia can be divided into simple, which consists of glands that are only mildly crowded with occasional outpouching, or complex, in which gland-to-stroma ratio is higher and glands appear disorganized with frequent luminal out-pouching. Cells lining the glands may show nuclear atypia, characterized by enlarged nuclei with hyper-chromatic nucleoli. Nuclear atypia is the most important factor for the progression to endometrial carcinoma.


Simple hyperplasia (Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons)


Complex hyperplasia (Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons)  

Option Analysis

❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: Early age of menarche is a risk factor of endometrial hyperplasia due to increased number of menstrual cycles, meaning increased estrogenic stimulation of the endometrium. This patient’s menarche occurred at the appropriate age.
❌ Age of menopause:
Incorrect: Late age of menopause is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia due to increased number of menstrual cycles, meaning increased estrogenic stimulation of the endometrium. This patient’s menopause occurred at the appropriate age.
✅ Body mass index:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Family history of diabetes:
Incorrect: Personal history, rather than family history, of diabetes is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia. This phenomenon is likely caused by hyperinsulinemia, which triggers endometrial growth. This patient does not have diabetes. 
❌ Paroxetine:
Incorrect: Medications that increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia include estrogen stimulating agents like tamoxifen and estrogen-only hormone replacement therapy. Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and has no effect on the endometrium.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of increasing abdominal girth and constipation for the past 3 months. She reports no associated nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain or abnormal vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and denies any pain during intercourse. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Current medications include combined oral contraceptives and multivitamins. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an enlarged, mobile, nontender, irregular uterus corresponding to 12-week sized gestation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with bulk related symptoms (constipation) and an irregularly enlarged (12-week sized) uterus is consistent with uterine leiomyoma.  

Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) are noncancerous monoclonal tumors of uterine smooth muscle cells. They are the most common pelvic tumor in females, with dominance among women of African descent. The tumor upregulates estrogen and progesterone receptors and increases the production of myometrial aromatase, promoting its growth on stimulation by these hormones, which is why it typically affects pre-menopausal women, grows rapidly during pregnancy, and is more common in nulliparous women. It usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menstrual bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (constipation, urinary incontinence, and pelvic pain), and reproductive dysfunction. The symptoms, however, may vary based on the location and size of the fibroid(s).  


Physical examination typically shows an enlarged, mobile and irregular uterus. Occasionally, fibroids undergo degeneration or torsion (common during pregnancy) resulting in an acute abdomen, low-grade fever ,and uterine tenderness. Additionally, they can sometimes distort the uterine cavity, causing infertility or increasing the risk of miscarriage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Uterine leiomyoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis usually presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, painful menses, pelvic pain and a uniformly enlarged boggy uterus. This patient’s bulk related symptoms (constipation) and an irregularly enlarged uterus would be atypical.          
❌ Pregnancy:
Incorrect: Although pregnancy should be excluded (using urine β-hCG) in all women of reproductive age with abdominal distension, this patient’s symptom duration, recent menstruation, and contraceptive history makes pregnancy unlikely.
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Although hypothyroidism may present with increased abdominal girth and constipation, the presence of an irregularly enlarged uterus and absence of other symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, cold intolerance, goiter) makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Endometriosis:
Incorrect: Endometriosis involving the rectovaginal septum or bowel can present with constipation. However, a fixed uterus with posterior cul-de-sac nodularity is usually observed. An irregularly enlarged uterus is not usually seen.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, presents to the office because of heavy and painful menstrual bleeding for the last 2 months. She reports soaking 12-15 sanitary pads during her last menses. Her menstrual cycle is regular, with 5-6 days of heavy bleeding. Menarche was at age 12. She is sexually active with one male partner and denies any pain during intercourse. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37° C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows an enlarged uterus with irregular contour. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Complete blood count is as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin (Hb)  9 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  75 fL 
 Hematocrit  32% 
 Leukocyte count  9,100/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  54% 
 Eosinophils  1% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  25% 
 Monocytes  4% 

A transvaginal ultrasound is performed.


Reproduced from: radiopedia.org  
Which of the following is the most likely origin of this patient’s ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with heavy and painful menstrual bleeding, findings of iron deficiency anemia (tachycardia, hypotension, low hemoglobin and MCV) and an irregularly enlarged uterus is consistent with uterine leiomyoma.  

Uterine leiomyoma is a noncancerous monoclonal tumor arising from uterine smooth muscle cells. It usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menstrual bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (constipation, urinary incontinence) and reproductive dysfunction. Physical examination typically shows an enlarged, mobile and irregular uterus. Diagnosis is usually based on transvaginal ultrasound findings of an iso- or hypoechoic well-circumscribed mass arising from the uterus. Calcifications may also be seen, especially if the fibroid has degenerated. Saline infusion sonography or hysteroscopy may also be used sometimes to visualize suspected sub-mucosal or intramural fibroids, particularly when the patient presents with infertility or a miscarriage or when ultrasound findings are inconclusive. In cases when malignancy is suspected, MRI is usually obtained to look for invasion and nodal involvement.

Morphologically, fibroids are sharply defined, round and firm grey-white tumors that vary in size from a nodule to massive pelvic tumors. Histologic examination shows interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells (whorled pattern) identical to cells of uninvolved myometrium.  



 Reproduced from: Flickr and Wikimedia Commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Placental epithelium:
Incorrect: Gestational trophoblastic diseases like hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma originate from placental epithelium. Although vaginal bleeding and an enlarged uterus is common, an ultrasound appearance of “snowstorm” or “Swiss cheese pattern” is typical. A negative pregnancy test further negates this diagnosis.
❌ Germ cell:
Incorrect: Common germ cell tumors in females include ovarian teratoma, dysgerminomas and yolk sac tumors. Although these may present with abdominal distention or vaginal bleeding, an irregularly enlarged uterus is atypical.
✅ Smooth muscle cell:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mesenchyme:
Incorrect: Connective tissue tumors like fibroma, lipoma, osteoma and chondroma are of mesenchymal origin. These are mostly asymptomatic or present with a mass depending on the location.
❌ Transitional epithelium:
Incorrect: Bladder cancer usually arises from transitional epithelium lining most of the urinary system and presents with hematuria and irritating voiding symptoms. A hard pelvic mass may be palpated in advanced cases, but an irregularly enlarged uterus would be atypical.

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulliparous woman presents to the office for the evaluation of infertility. She has been monogamous with her male partner for two years and has had unprotected intercourse regularly since then. She has also been experiencing episodic dull pelvic pain for the past 3 years that usually begins 3 days before menses and resolves after menstruation. She also complains of pain during sexual intercourse for the past 6 months. Her menstrual cycle is regular with periods occurring every 25th day and lasting for 6 days. She usually soaks 5-6 pads during her periods. The couple is currently not using contraception and has no history of sexually transmitted disease. She has had no hot flashes. Speculum examination reveals a moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized retroverted uterus. There is tenderness and nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. Semen analysis of her partner is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infertility in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with infertility and accompanying pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and dyspareunia (painful sexual intercourse) is most likely suffering from endometriosis.  

Endometriosis refers to implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grow and trigger an inflammatory response. It commonly involves the ovary, fallopian tubes and uterine ligament but can also affect other structures including the perimetrium, rectovaginal septum, recto-uterine pouch, bowel, diaphragm and pleural cavity. The pathogenesis of this condition is not well-established, although the prevailing theory is retrograde menstruation, in which endometrial cells flow backwards through the fallopian tubes and into the peritoneal cavity during menses. Other less popular theories include lymphatic dissemination, coelomic metaplasia, and a dysfunctional immune system.  

Endometriosis classically presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in posterior cul-de-sac). The inflammatory response associated with endometriosis causes scarring and adhesions of the reproductive structures, inhibiting the release of the ovum, its movement through the fallopian tube or its implantation in the uterus, ultimately causing infertility. Examination findings are variable depending upon the site involved and include tenderness on vaginal exam, posterior fornix nodularity, adnexal mass (endometrioma), and/or immobile uterus. Less common findings include dyschezia (posterior cul-de-sac), urinary frequency and urgency (bladder), and diarrhea/constipation (bowel).  

Option Analysis

❌ Asherman syndrome:
Incorrect: Asherman syndrome results from trauma to basal layer of endometrium leading to fibrosis and intrauterine adhesions. It is commonly caused by uterine manipulation and presents with amenorrhea. It is unlikely in this patient with dysmenorrhea and no history of uterine manipulation.
❌ Fibroids:
Incorrect: Uterine fibroids (leiomyoma) are usually asymptomatic but may present with heavy and painful menstrual bleeding, pressure symptoms like constipation, and infertility. Examination shows an enlarged and irregular uterus. It is unlikely in this patient with a normal-sized uterus and normal menstrual flow.
✅ Endometriosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial glandular tissue in the myometrium. Findings include heavy menstrual bleeding, dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and a uniformly enlarged uterus. It is unlikely in this patient with a normal-sized uterus and normal menstrual flow. 
❌ Premature ovarian failure:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with an irregular menstrual cycle and symptoms of hypoestrogenism (e.g., hot flashes, vaginal dryness), neither of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of chronic intermittent dull pelvic pain for 7 months. The pain usually begins a day before menses and resolves 1-2 days after the menstruation stops. She also complains of crampy pain with defecation. Menarche was at age 13. Her cycles are regular but are associated with heavy bleeding for 5 days. She is not sexually active, and there is no history of sexually transmitted disease. Family history is remarkable for ovarian cancer in her maternal grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows a fixed anteverted uterus and palpable right-sided adnexal mass. Transvaginal ultrasound of the right ovary is shown below.  


Reproduced from: radiopedia.org   

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with chronic intermittent pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, heavy menstrual bleeding, right-sided adnexal mass and fixed uterus, together with ultrasonographic evidence of a unilocular round hypoechoic density (endometrioma), is consistent with the diagnosis of endometriosis.  

Endometriosis is defined as implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grow and trigger an inflammatory response. It can involve the ovaries when the ectopic tissue in the ovary bleeds (in response to cyclic hormonal stimulation) and results in the formation of a hematoma surrounded by ovarian parenchyma (endometrioma), giving it a chocolate-like cyst appearance on gross examination. Subsequently, it can lead to nearby fibrosis and adhesion formation, causing infertility. On ultrasonography, endometrioma appears as a round hypoechoic density with homogenous contents (ground-glass appearance).   

Surgical resection provides a definitive diagnosis, symptom relief, and exclusion of malignancy. Other locations that can be involved in endometriosis include the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac (deep dyspareunia, dyschezia [pain with defecation]), broad ligaments, uterosacral ligaments, fallopian tubes, bladder (urinary frequency, urgency), and bowel (diarrhea, constipation).  

Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome:
Incorrect: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) usually presents with hyperandrogenic symptoms (hirsutism, acne) and irregular menstrual cycles. Diagnosis requires ultrasonographic evidence of 12 or more follicles measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter in the ovary. In contrast, this patient’s ultrasonography shows a single unilocular cyst.  
❌ Ovarian cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: Teratomas are benign germ cell tumors and are asymptomatic in most cases. However, an increase in size of the mass can cause ovarian torsion that presents with acute abdomen. On ultrasonography, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and sometimes calcifications.
✅ Endometriosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Epithelial ovarian carcinoma:
Incorrect: Epithelial ovarian carcinoma usually manifests in postmenopausal women with bloating, abdominal distention (due to ascites), constipation or pelvic mass. Ultrasonography shows a complex multilocular mass. It is unlikely in this young patient with a unilocular mass.
❌ Corpus luteal cyst:
Incorrect: Corpus luteal cyst is a physiological cyst that forms when the corpus luteum fails to involute after ovulation. On ultrasound, it appears as a simple or complex cyst with thick walls and internal debris (if hemorrhagic). It does not cause dysmenorrhea and dyschezia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of painless swelling around the right side of the labia minora. The patient is in good health and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Two-years ago, the patient was treated for a Chlamydia trachomatis infection. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Examination of the vulva reveals a 1 cm area of swelling and mild erythema on the posterior aspect of the labia majora. The affected area is located at the eight o'clock position with respect to the vaginal orifice. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with localized, non-painful swelling on the posterior aspect of the labia minora at the eight o'clock position, which is suggestive of a greater vestibular gland cyst.    

The greater vestibular glands, also known as Bartholin glands, are pea-sized glands found on the posterior aspect of the labia majora at approximately 4 and 8 o'clock positions with respect to the vaginal orifice. These glands secrete mucus to lubricate the vagina. Bartholin gland cysts occur due to obstruction of the duct opening. These cysts may evolve into abscesses. Vulvar abscesses are usually due to mixed polymicrobial infections, consisting mainly of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), enteric gram-negative aerobes, and anaerobes.    

Patients with a Bartholin cyst typically present with a painless and asymptomatic mass. Larger cysts may lead to discomfort during sexual intercourse, sitting, or ambulating. Abscesses, however, are usually painful and may present with fever.  

Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, and physical exam may reveal the presence of a mass in the lower medial labia minora or vulvar vestibule. Management of a Bartholin gland mass depends on its size and whether it is a cyst or abscess. In general, larger cysts or abscesses (≥3 cm) are an indication for incision and drainage, while smaller lesions may be treated with conservative therapy such as warm compresses or sitz baths. Antibiotics may be added for abscess treatment.


Option Analysis

❌ Hair follicle:
Incorrect: Hair follicle infections are common sites of infection and abscess formation. The mons pubis and labia majora are covered with hair but not the labia minora. While hair follicle infection is common, this patient’s lesion is located in the posterior aspect of the labia minora, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌  Paraurethral glands  :
Incorrect: Paraurethral glands (also known as the lesser vestibular glands or Skene glands) are located on the anterior vaginal wall, around the lower end of the urethra. These glands are responsible for the secretion of fluid that helps lubricate the urethral opening. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is located posterior to the vaginal opening, which instead raises greater concern for a Batholin gland cyst. 
✅ Greater vestibular glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Urethral mucosa:
Incorrect: A urethral diverticulum refers to the localized outpouching of the urethral mucosa. Patients may present with the classic triad of postvoid dribbling, dysuria, and dyspareunia. In addition, patients may experience recurrent urinary tract infections, hematuria, and increased urinary frequency. On physical examination, an anterior vaginal wall mass is often found. In contrast, this patient lacks the symptoms characteristic of a urethral diverticulum and has a lesion posterior to the vaginal opening. 
❌  Sebaceous glands  :
Incorrect: Sebaceous gland cysts, also known as epidermal inclusion cysts, are caused by an accumulation of the squamous epithelium below the epidermis due to obstruction of the pilosebaceous ducts or secondary to trauma. They are often found on the vulva. The cysts vary in size, are typically round, and are skin-colored, yellow, or white. This patient’s lesion and location favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician due to progressive vaginal pruritus and painful defecation that began one-month ago. The itching often awakens her at night. She is generally healthy and has reached all childhood developmental milestones. She has not yet had a menstrual period. In the office, her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is Tanner stage 1. Vaginal examination shows multiple white, atrophic papules and plaques that cover the labia minora and extend to the perineum. Multiple hemorrhagic foci are also noted. Rectal examination reveals an anal fissure. This patient’s condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This premenarchal girl is presenting with vaginal pruritus, multiple white, atrophic, papules and plaques over the labia major, and an anal fissure. She most likely has lichen sclerosis.  

Lichen sclerosis is a benign, chronic dermatologic disorder typified by inflammation, epithelial thinning, and dermal changes. Patients may present with vulvar pruritus, anal discomfort (anal fissure or painful defection), dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesions are usually white, atrophic papules that may fuse into plaques. The lesions are sometimes described as porcelain-white paper-like plaques. The lesions commonly affect the labia minora and/or labia majora and may extend to the perineum. Scratching can cause secondary hemorrhage and hyperkeratosis.    

The condition may occur at any age but usually follows a bimodal distribution; one peak is seen in prepubertal girls and a second in peri/postmenopausal women. Both of these are physiologically low-estrogen states. The condition is also associated with genetic factors (runs in families), autoimmune conditions, and local factors (skin graft). Patients with vulvar lichen sclerosis are at increased risk of developing squamous cell cancer of the vulva, and therefore diagnostic biopsy is recommended in adult patients. Treatment usually includes a highly potent topical corticosteroid ointment, such as clobetasol.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low estrogen levels :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Low fiber diet :
Incorrect: Constipation due to a low-fiber diet can result in anal fissure formation and painful defecation. However, it would not account for the vulvar itching or the plaques observed on physical examination. 
❌ Mite infestation of the skin:
Incorrect: Sarcoptes scabiei is a mite capable of infesting the skin and causing intense pruritus. The condition commonly affects the webs of the fingers, wrists, axillae, areolae, and genitalia. Typical skin findings include multiple small, erythematous, papules and burrows. This patient is presenting only with vulvar and perineal lesions, which makes scabies less likely. Moreover, a scabies infection would likely spread to other members of her household, and they would experience similar symptoms.  
❌ Chronic irritation :
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus refers to non-neoplastic hyperplasia of vulvar squamous epithelium caused by chronic irritation. It typically presents as leathery, thick vulvar skin from scratching. This patient’s lesion is atrophic, which favors another diagnosis. Moreover, lichen simplex chronicus is usually a diagnosis of exclusion.  
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Condylomata acuminata, also known as anogenital warts, is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. The most common strains are HPV types 6 and 11. The lesions typically manifest as soft cauliflower-shaped, white/skin-colored/erythematous growths on the external genitalia. In contrast, it would be atypical for anogenital warts to manifest as atrophic papules and plaques.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic for the evaluation of irregular periods. For the last three years, the patient has had about four periods a year. She recently began shaving her upper lip and chin due to excessive hair growth. Review of systems is significant for 30 lbs weight gain in the last 7 months. Past medical history is unremarkable. She has a family history of breast cancer in her mother at age 49 and myocardial infarction in her father at age 52. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows terminal hair on the upper lip and nipples. The abdomen is obese and nontender with no masses or tenderness. Development is Tanner stage V. A transvaginal ultrasound shows polycystic ovaries bilaterally. Serum TSH is within normal limits. Which of the following sets of hormonal changes will most likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical evidence of the hyperandrogenism (hirsutism), irregular menses, and obesity typical of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The ultrasound finding of polycystic ovaries further supports the diagnosis.

PCOS is caused by dysfunction in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis. The anterior pituitary makes too much LH (the mechanism is not well known), which can exceed twice the level of FSH. Excessive LH causes the theca cells to produce excess amounts of androstenedione, which is converted into estrone by aromatase in the adipose tissue, and reduced levels of sex-hormone binding globulin. High estrone levels cause high pulses of GnRH from the hypothalamus. The high pulses of GnRH produce an imbalance of LH/FSH release from the pituitary which results in a lack of LH surge. This leads to the failure of follicle maturation and oocyte release. As a result, ovulation does not occur. However, an elevated LH-to-FSH ratio is not a criterion for the diagnosis of PCOS, as their levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

High levels of androstenedione from polycystic ovary syndrome can cause hirsutism. It can also lead to male-pattern baldness, as well as acne on the face, chest, and back. Lack of ovulation causes amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea, both of which can cause infertility.  

Option Analysis

❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↓↓↓:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is caused by the decreased amplitude and/or frequency of gonadotropin pulses from the hypothalamus, leading to decreased levels of LH, FSH and estradiol. It can occur in females who maintain a very low calorie diet.
✅  GnRH FSH  Estrogen ↑Normal↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↑↑↓:
Incorrect: This set of findings is usually seen in patients with primary ovarian insufficiency, which is the cessation of ovarian function at age <40. It is characterized by oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea in combination with symptoms of estrogen deficiency (e.g. hot flashes and vaginal dryness).
❌  GnRH FSH  Estrogen NormalNormalNormal:
Incorrect: Normal hormonal levels are indicative of normal ovulation and is unlikely in this patient with irregular menstrual cycle and signs of hyperandrogenism. Such levels can also be seen in patients with imperforate hymen who present with cyclic abdominal pain and a vaginal bulge, neither of which is seen in this patient.
❌   GnRH  FSH  Estrogen ↓↓↑:
Incorrect: Exogenous estrogen administration decreases serum GnRH and FSH levels via negative feedback. It is unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, presents to the office for evaluation of an abnormal routine Pap smear. She has been healthy and has no vaginal spotting or bleeding. The cervical cytology showed atypical glandular cells. Menarche was at age 14, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until menopause at the age of 47. Past medical history is significant for osteoporosis treated with raloxifene. She also took hormone replacement therapy for hot flashes for two years after menopause. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 31.5 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows loss of labial fullness and an atrophic vagina. Bimanual examination is significant for a small uterus. Endometrial sampling is performed, and histology shows complex papillary architecture with the presence of round calcific collections and marked nuclear atypia. Which of the following risk factors in this patient’s history is the most significant in the development of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of low estrogen (loss of labial fullness, atrophic vagina), small uterus (suggestive of endometrial atrophy), together with histopathological findings of complex papillary architecture, psammoma bodies and nuclear atypia (high nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio, hyperchromasia and prominent nucleoli), is consistent with the diagnosis of type II (serous) endometrial carcinoma.

 

 Endometrial carcinoma is the most common gynecological cancer in the developed countries. It is classified into 2 subtypes on the basis of histopathology:  

  •  Type I carcinoma: also known as endometrioid carcinoma due to its histologic resemblance to endometrial glands. It is known to arise from endometrial hyperplasia usually in the setting of increased estrogen exposure. 
  •  Type II carcinoma: a rare and more aggressive tumor which is not estrogen dependent. It presents as postmenopausal vaginal bleeding or as an incidental finding of abnormal cervical cytology (as seen in this patient). The most common type is serous, arising from an atrophic endometrium. Advanced age is a major risk factor. A mutation in p53 is commonly observed in early carcinogenesis. This tumor has a high tendency for lymphovascular invasion as well as intraperitoneal and extra-abdominal spread.

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: A history of endometrial cancer (not breast cancer) in a first-degree relative is considered a risk factor in the development of endometrial cancer. Germline mutations of BRCA genes are associated with the cancers of breast and ovary (not endometrium). Lynch syndrome, in contrast, is associated with an increased risk of colonic, endometrial, and ovarian cancers. 
✅ Age of the patient:
Incorrect: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of hormone replacement therapy:
Incorrect: Increased estrogen exposure (as a result of hormone replacement, early menopause or tamoxifen) is considered a risk factor in the development of type I (endometrioid) endometrial carcinoma. The presence of psammoma bodies (round calcific collections) on histopathology and endometrial atrophy (small uterus) in this patient makes type II endometrial cancer more likely.  
❌ Age of menarche:
Incorrect: Although early age of menarche is considered a significant risk factor for the development of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma, this patient’s age of menarche is appropriate.
❌ Raloxifene use:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is sometimes used for the prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. Unlike tamoxifen and estrogens, raloxifene does not increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the office because of vaginal spotting, abdominal distention and constipation for the past 3 months. She is also having difficulty defecating and often has to put her index and middle finger in her vagina to aid in pushing the stools out. Menopause was at age 48. Past history is significant for breast cancer treated by breast-sparing mastectomy and tamoxifen. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows an enlarged irregular uterus and normal rectal tone. Transvaginal doppler ultrasound shows mixed echogenic masses with increased vascularity and central necrosis, bulging into the uterine cavity. Hysterectomy is performed which reveals a poorly-demarcated large yellow soft mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histology of the specimen is shown.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with postmenopausal bleeding, bulk-related symptoms (constipation) and abdominal distention, in combination with histopathology showing smooth muscle cells of irregular size and hyperchromatic nuclei, is consistent with uterine leiomyosarcoma.  

Leiomyosarcoma is a rare tumor and usually arises in women after the age of 40. Common risk factors include tamoxifen use, history of pelvic irradiation and some hereditary syndromes (e.g. hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma [HLRCC] syndrome). It is important to note that leiomyosarcomas arise de novo and not from benign leiomyomas or from myometrial or endometrial stromal cells.  

The increasing size of the mass can sometimes put pressure on adjacent organs, leading to bulk-related symptoms (e.g. constipation). Patients usually report relieving of pressure by “splinting”, which helps in defecation by manually deflecting the obstruction. Although the clinical presentation is somewhat similar to leiomyoma, the diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma is considered when the symptoms occur after menopause and doppler ultrasound shows a poorly-demarcated mass with increased vascularity and mixed echogenicity suggestive of hemorrhage and necrosis. Grossly, it appears as a soft yellow-colored mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histopathology shows smooth muscle cells of irregular size and nuclear atypia (hyperchromatic nuclei).  


Courtesy of Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease (9th ed.)  



Option Analysis

❌ Uterine polyps:
Incorrect: Uterine polyps are the hyperplastic growths of tissue from the endometrial surface which usually present with intermenstrual bleeding. Bulk-related symptoms with an irregularly enlarged uterus as seen in this patient would be atypical.
❌ Uterine leiomyoma:
Incorrect: Although the clinical presentation of this patient is similar to that of leiomyoma, soft yellow masses with hemorrhagic areas and irregular smooth muscle cells on histology are consistent with a more malignant process, such as leiomyosarcoma.
✅ Uterine leiomyosarcoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: Endometrial cancer may present with postmenopausal bleeding, but it is usually associated with a thick endometrial stripe on ultrasound. Histology shows glandular architecture mixed with solid areas, not irregular smooth muscle cells.
❌ Adenomyosis:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis may also present with abnormal uterine bleeding, but a uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus is usually seen on physical examination. Histopathology shows ectopic endometrial tissue in the myometrium.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to vulvar itching over the past few months. The patient reports experiencing an irritating itch that often awakens her at night. She has tried multiple lotions without relief. Medical history is remarkable for atopic dermatitis, which has been effectively managed with a steroid cream. The patient does not have any burning sensation during urination, dyschezia, or dyspareunia. The patient has no history of sexually transmitted diseases and is in a monogamous relationship with her partner. The patient’s temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination of the vulva reveals a thick, leathery lesion covering most of the left labia majora. A close up of the lesion is shown below:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia

 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has intense pruritus and a thick, leather-like lesion isolated to the labia majora, which is consistent with the diagnosis of lichen simplex chronicus.    

Lichen simplex chronicus is a skin condition caused by long-standing scratching, which results in epithelial thickening and hyperkeratosis. The exact pathogenesis is not well understood, but it is hypothesized that chronic stimulation of the cutaneous nerve results in nerve dysfunction, which accentuates the “itch-scratch” cycle. It may arise secondary to other conditions, specifically atopic dermatitis. Patients typically present with extremely pruritic, leathery, thick skin and enhanced skin markings. These lesions are common on the neck, genitals, or dorsum of the foot.    

In contrast to lichen sclerosis, lichen simplex chronicus does not increase the risk of cancer. Diagnosis is usually done clinically but a biopsy may be done to exclude other conditions. Treatment focuses on halting the itch-scratch cycle and involves topical and intralesional corticosteroids. 

Option Analysis

❌ Extramammary Paget disease:
Incorrect: Paget disease of the vulva is an intraepithelial adenocarcinoma seen usually in patients > 60 years of age. Similar to Paget disease of the breast, the lesion is eczematous-like, well-demarcated, and has raised edges. Gross examination will reveal an erythematous background dotted with pale islands. Pruritus is the most common symptom. In contrast, this patient’s lesion is thickened, white, and leathery, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Lichen sclerosis:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosis is a benign, chronic dermatologic disorder typified by inflammation, epithelial thinning, and dermal changes. It is often seen in prepubertal girls and peri/postmenopausal women and is associated with a low estrogen state. Patients often present with vulvar pruritus, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesion manifests as porcelain-white, thin paper-like plaques. This patient’s lesion is instead thickened, while lichen sclerosis leads to thinning of the skin. Also, other than pruritus, the patient is not experiencing any other symptom associated with lichen sclerosis.  
❌ Vitiligo:
Incorrect: Vitiligo is an acquired pigmentation disorder characterized by irregular patches of complete depigmentation due to destruction of melanocytes. It is believed to be an autoimmune condition and often accompanies other autoimmune conditions. Although lesions may appear anywhere on the body, they are asymptomatic and would not cause pruritus.  
✅ Lichen simplex chronicus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratoses are benign epidermal tumors arising from the proliferation of immature keratinocytes. The condition is often seen in individuals > 50 years of age. The lesions are flat, well-demarcated, greasy, and often described as having a “stuck on” appearance. Lesions occur on the head, trunk, and extremities. It would be atypical for seborrheic keratoses to manifest in the vulva.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to vaginal pruritus and eczema over the past month. She has tried multiple creams, including corticosteroids, with no relief. She is generally healthy and does not smoke or use alcohol. There is no history of sexually transmitted diseases or abnormal Pap smears. The patient has had 3-lifetime sexual partners and is currently in a monogamous relationship with her partner of 35 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 142/86 mmHg.  Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated, eczematous lesion with raised edges that covers most of the left labia majora. A biopsy is obtained and shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with an eczematous-like rash on the vulva which did not respond to topical creams, and the biopsy results show tumor cells with clear cytoplasm (clear halo) infiltrating the epidermis, a classic picture of Paget disease. Paget cells stain positive for mucin on Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) staining.    

Paget disease refers to the intraepidermal proliferation of epithelial cells in the skin of the nipple or the vulva. While virtually all cases of Paget disease of the nipple are associated with an underlying adenocarcinoma, only a minority of cases of extramammary Paget disease have an underlying tumor. Instead, Paget cells in the vulva commonly arise from proliferation of epidermal progenitor cells. The lesions of Paget disease usually appear as red, scaly, crusted plaque that may mimic the appearance of eczema, but the lack of response to steroids distinguishes the lesions from eczema.  

Option Analysis

❌ Low-estrogen physiologic states:
Incorrect: Lichen sclerosis is a benign skin condition seen in prepubertal girls and peri/postmenopausal women. It is associated with low estrogen state, genetic factors, infections, and immunologic abnormalities. Patients often present with vulvar pruritus, dyschezia, dyspareunia, and dysuria. The lesion manifests as porcelain-white, thin paper-like plaques. Treatment includes topical corticosteroid cream. The condition predisposes to vulvar cancer, and a biopsy is recommended to rule-out malignancy. This patient’s histological findings suggest a different diagnosis. 
❌  Hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: Lichen simplex chronicus refers to thickening and hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium as a result of chronic scratching and irritation. Patients often present with pruritic, leathery, thick skin and enhanced skin markings on the vulva. It is not associated with an increased risk of cancer.  
❌ Infection with oncogenic virus:
Incorrect: Infection by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16,18, and 33 is associated with increased risk for developing vaginal and vulvar cancer. The lesions are usually warty or Bowenoid type, multifocal, and tend to be poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinomas. However, this patient’s histology is consistent with extramammary Paget disease, which is not associated with HPV infection.  
✅ Proliferation of epidermal progenitor cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Proliferation of malignant basal cells:
Incorrect: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin cancer and is usually found in sun-exposed areas. The lesions are usually pink, waxy, and occasionally exhibit pearly nodules and telangiectasias. On histology, basal cell tumors show a “palisading” pattern.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 4, presents to the clinic for the evaluation of vaginal spotting between menses for the past 2 months. Her cycles were regular before that. She has no history of dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. Menarche was at age 13 years. Past medical history is significant for breast cancer, generalized anxiety disorder, hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include tamoxifen, paroxetine, amlodipine and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a normal-sized uterus without tenderness. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a pedunculated pearl-shaped mass arising from the uterine body. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface

questions.solution:
This patient with intermenstrual bleeding while on tamoxifen therapy and the ultrasound finding of pedunculated pearl-shaped mass most likely has an endometrial polyp.  

An endometrial polyp is defined as the hyperplastic overgrowth of endometrial glands and stroma from the surface of the endometrium. It can occur in both premenopausal or postmenopausal women and typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. Intermenstrual bleeding is the most frequent symptom in premenopausal women with endometrial polyps. However, it may sometimes be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging or abnormal cervical cytology.  

Risk factors include obesity, tamoxifen therapy and hormone replacement therapy, all of which stimulate the endometrial tissue, resulting in its proliferation, which may lead to the development of endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, or cancer. Physical examination is usually normal except in the case of a prolapsed polyp, in which a friable, pedunculated lesion can be seen protruding from the external cervical os. Ultrasound helps in localizing the lesion while definitive diagnosis is established on histologic evaluation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial tissue in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. Although abnormal uterine bleeding is commonly seen, the condition is associated with abdominal pain and an enlarged, boggy and tender uterus on examination.
✅ Hyperplastic overgrowth of tissue from endometrial surface:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the endometrium:
Incorrect: Inflammation of endometrium (endometritis) commonly presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain and fever. The condition is usually associated with recent childbirth, an intrauterine procedure, or a genitourinary infection.
❌ Benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation:
Incorrect: Uterine leiomyoma (fibroids) result from benign myometrial smooth muscle proliferation. The condition usually presents with heavy and/or prolonged menses, mass-effect symptoms such as constipation and an irregularly enlarged uterus. This patient has a normal-sized uterus.
❌ Ectopic endometrial tissue:
Incorrect: Endometriosis refers to presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. It commonly presents with dysmenorrhea (not intermenstrual bleeding), pelvic pain and deep dyspareunia. The uterus is normal in size but is usually immobile (fixed).

questions.text: A 23-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the office because of chronic episodic pelvic pain. The pain begins 2-3 days before menses and continues throughout the menses, after which it subsides. Menarche was at age 14. She has a regular menstrual cycle of 25 days with 5-6 days of moderate bleeding. Medical history is significant for recurrent migraine headaches with aura. She is not sexually active. Physical examination shows a fixed anteverted uterus and nodularity in the posterior cul-de-sac. The patient is provided with a medication that acts to inhibit the growth of endometrial tissue. Which of the following medications was most likely provided?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical findings of chronic episodic pelvic pain, immobile (fixed) uterus, and posterior cul-de-sac nodularity highly suggest the diagnosis of endometriosis.  

Endometriosis is defined as implantation of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrium that grow and trigger an inflammatory response. It is a chronic condition that requires optimizing the approach for the management of related symptoms based on their severity. Patients with mild pain are usually managed with combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and as-needed non-steroids anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For those with contraindications to combined OCPs (such as migraine with aura, like this patient; for detailed list of contraindications, see table), progestin-only pills (POP) are an acceptable alternative, which act by inhibiting the growth of endometrial tissue.  

Laparoscopic resection of ectopic endometrial tissue is considered the gold standard and is both diagnostic and therapeutic. However, those with mild symptoms or those who decline surgery should be treated with medical therapy. Other medical treatment options which are reserved for patients with severe or recurrent symptoms include danazol, GnRH analogues, and aromatase inhibitors.



Option Analysis

❌ Paroxetine:
Incorrect: Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and has no effect on the endometrium. 
✅ Progestin-only contraceptive pills:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Clomiphene:
Incorrect: Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is used for ovulation induction. It works by inhibiting the negative feedback on the hypothalamus and pituitary gland, thereby increasing follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). While endometriosis does predispose to infertility, this patient is not sexually active and is not planning for pregnancy at this time. 
❌ Danazol:
Incorrect: Danazol inhibits mid-cycle surges of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) and prevents steroidogenesis in the corpus luteum. Although it is effective in treating endometriosis-related pain, it is not the preferred option due to its androgenic side effects (acne, edema, weight gain, hirsutism, and gynecomastia). 
❌ Anastrozole:
Incorrect: Anastrozole acts by inhibiting aromatase, the enzyme that converts androgens to estrogens, thereby regulating estrogen formation in the endometriotic lesions. Its off-label use for treating endometriosis-related pain is reserved for women with severe refractory pain because of limited data and the risk of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 2, presents to the office for evaluation of amenorrhea. Menarche was at age 12, and she had a regular 28-day cycle with no dysmenorrhea until four months ago when her cycle stopped. Past medical history is significant for two missed abortions, the last of which was six months ago, managed via dilation and curettage. She has a healthy five-year-old girl and a three-year-old boy born via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is not taking any medications currently. Family history is significant for hypothyroidism in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 22 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Speculum examination shows moist vaginal mucosa with no abnormalities. Urine beta-HCG is negative. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. A progesterone withdrawal test is performed with no withdrawal bleeding. An estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test is performed. Bleeding is absent again. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of secondary amenorrhea, a history of an intrauterine procedure (dilation and curettage), routine laboratory findings, and absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge test and estrogen/progesterone withdrawal test make the diagnosis of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) most likely.

A 10-day medroxyprogesterone test (progestin challenge) assesses uterine function. It involves administering 10 milligrams of medroxyprogesterone daily for ten days to see if that induces menstrual bleeding. A healthy uterus should bleed. If there’s no bleeding, estrogen is given to thicken the uterine lining, and medroxyprogesterone is added. Failure to bleed strongly suggests endometrial scarring.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea:
Incorrect: Functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) is a disorder caused by disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Common risk factors include stress, anorexia nervosa, and excessive exercise.  The condition is most commonly seen in young athletes. The cause of amenorrhea in this patient with normal lifestyle habits and a healthy body mass index is unlikely. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Endometriosis:
Incorrect:  Endometriosis presents in women of reproductive age with pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, dysmenorrhea, and deep dyspareunia (due to lesions in the posterior cul-de-sac). This patient has had none of these complaints, making this diagnosis less likely.  
✅ Asherman syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Primary ovarian insufficiency:
Incorrect: Accelerated follicular depletion can be due to primary ovarian insufficiency or secondary to follicular atresia due to other causes (radiation, chemotherapy, autoimmune). It commonly presents with irregular menstrual cycles, hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and elevated FSH levels, none seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels and absence of bleeding on the progesterone challenge test suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Although amenorrhea can be seen in hypothyroidism, it is usually accompanied by fatigue, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and other findings not seen in this patient. Additionally, this patient’s normal hormone levels make this cause less likely. The absence of bleeding on progesterone challenge tests suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician due to significant pain during her menstrual cycles. The patient tells the physician that this started eight months ago and has been interfering with her activities of daily living. After an appropriate workup, the diagnosis of endometriosis is made. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that has pro-androgenic effects and anti-estrogenic effects. Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with endometriosis, a condition in which the endometrial gland grows outside the uterine cavity. Many options can be used in treating endometriosis, one of which is danazol.

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with androgen agonist and antagonist effects on estrogen. Danazol suppresses ovarian function through both direct and indirect effects. It directly inhibits ovarian function by inhibiting the ovary's steroidogenesis and indirectly decreases estrogen synthesis by decreasing the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. It also has androgenic agonist effects, as it stimulates androgen receptors.

Danazol has been proven to be effective in treating endometriosis. By creating amenorrhea and hypoestrogenism, danazol causes atrophy and regression of the ectopic endometrial tissues. Its use in treating endometriosis has decreased pain and improved fertility.

However, it is not usually used as a first-line treatment option because of its androgenic side effects i.e. acne, voice changes (e.g., deepening of the voice, hoarseness), decreased breast size, and hirsutism. Additionally, it may lead to menstrual irregularities, flushing, and sweating. Sometimes, patients can have nausea, vomiting, and a rise in blood pressure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Danazol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leuprolide:
Incorrect: Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that can sometimes be used to treat endometriosis; it has no androgenic effects.  
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) are the first-line treatment of endometriosis and be efficacious in reducing pain. However, they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Progestin-only pills:
Incorrect: Progestin-only pills can also be used in treating endometriosis, but they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: NSAIDs are usually used to control pain in endometriosis patients; however, they do not directly influence the hormones in the body.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of endometriosis. The patient was diagnosed nine months ago, and she has taken combined oral contraceptives and ibuprofen. The patient continues to experience significant pain with menstruation and sexual intercourse. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, and pulse is 64/min. Pelvic examination is notable for rectovaginal tenderness and nodularity of the uterosacral ligament. The patient is initiated on a new medication that binds directly to GnRH receptors.  When this medication is administered continuously, it can lead to the downregulation of GnRH receptors. Which of the following side effects is this patient at risk of developing after starting this new medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with endometriosis and was started on a GnRH agonist, which can cause reduced bone density and osteoporosis.

GnRH agonists (e.g., leuprolide, nafarelin, triptorelin) bind to GnRH receptors in the pituitary gland. These medications can be given in either a pulsatile or continuous fashion. When administered in a pulsatile pattern, they mimic the physiological secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. GnRH agonists bind and activate GnRH receptors, thereby increasing the downstream synthesis of LH, FSH, and sex hormones. This method of administration was historically used to treat infertility but is rarely used nowadays due to the availability of better alternatives.

In contrast, continuous administration of GnRH agonists caused an initial, transient stimulation of GnRH receptors and increased sex hormone synthesis. Over time this results in a downregulation in the number of GnRH receptors, and the body becomes less sensitive to the hormone. These changes decrease the downstream synthesis of LH, FSH, and sex hormones. Continuous administration can treat endometriosis, uterine fibroids, prostate cancer, and precocious puberty.

When given continuously, the medication can cause menopause-like and andropause-like side effects. These symptoms include hot flashes, reduced bone density, decreased libido, and impotence and gynecomastia in men. Furthermore, patients may experience nausea/vomiting, lightheadedness, and injection site irritation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients taking estrogen-containing contraceptives are at risk for developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This patient was initiated on a GnRH analog (e.g. leuprolide). GnRH analogs can predispose patients to develop menopause-like symptoms like nausea, hot flashes, and osteoporosis.  
❌ Endometrial malignancy:
Incorrect: Exogenous estrogen use and specific selective estrogen receptor modulators (e.g. tamoxifen) can increase the risk of developing endometrial cancer. These medications do not directly bind to GnRH receptors.  
❌ Pelvic inflammatory disease:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on a GnRH agonist to treat endometriosis. However, GnRH agonists are not known to increase the risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease. GnRH agonists can cause menopause-like and andropause-like symptoms, including hot flashes, osteoporosis, reduced libido, impotence, and gynecomastia (in men). Furthermore, patients may experience nausea, lightheadedness, and injection site irritation.  
✅ Reduced bone density:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome:
Incorrect: Clomiphene acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in the hypothalamus, reducing estrogenic negative feedback inhibition. These changes ultimately result in increased LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland. Clomiphene can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, manifest with abdominal distention/pain, rapid weight gain, dyspnea, and respiratory distress. GnRH agonists (e.g. leuprolide) are not associated with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of exertional dyspnea and difficulty with ambulation. She has not experienced chest pain, syncope, or loss of consciousness but states she cannot climb a flight of stairs without feeling winded. She also reports gait instability and difficulty keeping her balance while standing. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, untreated HIV, and chronic hepatitis C infection. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and glyburide. The patient is not sexually active and is post-menopausal. She lives in Connecticut with her niece and went on a camping trip six weeks ago. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/65 mmHg. Physical examination reveals granulomatous lesions with heaped borders on the patient’s lips, right leg, and arm. On cardiac auscultation, the apical impulse is displaced laterally and inferiorly with the presence of an early diastolic murmur over the left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple wart-like lesions on the labia majora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Neurological examination reveals a positive Romberg sign and loss of vibration perception with intact motor function. Ophthalmic examination is notable for an absent light reflex with a retained accommodation reflex. Which of the following historical features is the most likely etiology of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Cohabitation with a person with a similar illness

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, a wide pulse pressure, and a new diastolic murmur–consistent with aortic regurgitation. In addition, the physical exam reveals evidence of gummatous lesions and neurological symptoms (positive Romberg sign, loss of proprioception, and sense of vibration) that suggest posterior column degeneration (tabes dorsalis). Lastly, the pupillary exam reveals a characteristically absent light reflex with a retained accommodation reflex (Argyll Robertson pupil). Together, these findings are highly concerning for tertiary syphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.

Tertiary syphilis develops in patients with long-standing untreated syphilis and often presents with evidence of disseminated infection to multiple organ systems. Classically, tertiary syphilis presents with cardiovascular (aortitis), dermatologic (gumma), and neurologic symptoms (tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil).

Classically, tertiary syphilis causes obliterative endarteritis of the vasa vasorum within the adventitia of the ascending thoracic aorta. Ultimately, this weakening of the aortic wall results in chronic aortitis, aortic root dilation, and subsequent aortic regurgitation. The associated skin lesions of tertiary syphilis are characterized by gummatous lesions, which are granulomatous, heaped lesions on the lips, skin of the extremities, bones, and viscera. Neurologically, infection of the posterior column of the spinal cord results in tabes dorsalis, with symptoms including the loss of proprioception and vibration sense due to posterior column degeneration.

Diagnostic investigations of tertiary syphilis include non-treponemal (VDRL, RPR) and treponemal (FTA-ABS, TP-EIA) antibody tests.  Specific investigations to confirm neurosyphilis include lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination and CSF-VDRL tests. A nonreactive CSF-VDRL test does not rule out a diagnosis of neurosyphilis; however, an elevated protein concentration and a CSF lymphocyte count of > 5 cells/microL are indicative of neurosyphilis in patients with high suspicion despite a negative CSF-VDRL test. The treatment of choice for neurosyphilis is ten to fourteen days of either intravenous penicillin or intramuscular penicillin plus probenecid.

Option Analysis

✅ Unprotected sexual intercourse:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Arthropod bite:
